Authors: Matthew J. Zidek, Lin Yu, Michael Jochum, YOUNG-KI JO
Title:
Complexities of Gaeumannomyces species causing take-all root
rot of St. Augustinegrass
Keywords: Gaeumannomyces, St. Augustinegrass, take-all root rot
Abstract:
Gaeumannomyces graminis var. graminis (Ggg) has been the
etiological agent of take-all root rot (TARR) of St. Augustinegrass
(Stenotaphrum secundatum) and root decline of the other warm-season
turfgrasses. We isolated 76 Ggg isolates from St. Augustinegrass in
central and eastern Texas. Evaluation of colony morphologies on potato
dextrose agar and follow-up multi-locus phylogenic analysis revealed
three phenotypic groups associated with different Gaeumannomyces
species: (i) G. floridanus, highly melanized with round colony
formation, (ii) G. arxii, non to slightly melanized with round colony
formation, and (iii) G. graminicola, highly melanized with irregular
colony formation. Representative isolates from each group were subjected
to further phenotypic and genetic characterizations. Most tested G.
floridanus isolates were adapted to warmer temperatures than G. arxii or
G. graminicola. Pathogenicity assays using rice seedlings indicated that
G. floridanus was more aggressive than G. arxii or G. graminicola. A
multi-locus phylogeny reconstruction supported that these three groups
were phylogenetically distinct, grouped with previously published
Gaeumannomyces taxa, and separated into three different clades,
Oryzinus, Graminis and Tritici. The resolution of intravarietal
complexities of TARR associated with different Gaeumannomyces species is
important for proper diagnostics and management strategies for TARR and
other root-decline diseases in warm-season turfgrasses.
